One Labor-Lovers Pizza, Coming Right Up
Workers at Barboncino Pizza in Brooklyn are forming New York City‚Äôs first pizzeria union. They announced last week on
that a supermajority of the restaurant‚Äôs staff has signed on with Workers United.
It all began one particularly trying night in the summer of 2022 (the incident became known as ‚Äúpoop night‚Äù;

if you dare). After a callous response from management, workers reached out to the Emergency Workplace Organizing Committee (EWOC), an organization that helps with the early stages of union campaigns. The pizzeria staff connected with Workers United, filed with the NLRB for a union election, and are now fighting for a living wage, protections against arbitrary terminations, and clarity on disciplinary policies.
Food service workers are nationally underrepresented in organized labor:

to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, only 1.6 percent of food service workers are unionized, compared to 7.7 percent of health care and social assistance workers and 15.2 percent of education workers. That makes the pizzeria‚Äôs move to unionize particularly powerful, and staff ‚Äì‚Äì  emphasizing that their real fight is with the whole food-service industry, not Barboncino ‚Äì‚Äì hopes their organizing can inspire a broader movement.

. ‚ÄúIf we can organize, any other nearby restaurant can too, and they‚Äôll do it twice as quickly as we did.‚Äù

children.text: National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) Lawyer Jennifer Abruzzo sent out a
last Tuesday declaring that noncompete clauses violate federal laws protecting workers‚Äô rights to union organizing and collective action.

Noncompete clauses prevent workers from taking jobs with rival companies for a period of time after employment. These clauses, impacting one in five American workers, weaken workers‚Äô bargaining and collective action power in labor negotiations. And while corporations say they help maintain trade secrets and confidential information, these clauses often
to workers who don‚Äôt even handle trade secrets in the first place.
we mentioned that four states have already banned noncompetes: California, North Dakota, Oklahoma, and most recently, Minnesota. The Federal Trade Commission
banning noncompete clauses in January, and has estimated that a ban could increase annual employee earnings by almost $300
The memo isn‚Äôt a law or a binding rule, but it‚Äôs part of a growing trend to address the dangers of noncompetes, and could
local NLRB offices more effectively challenge these clauses to create binding legal precedents going forward.

Since 2020, Taking Ownership PDX has raised $1.7 million and helped more than 160 Black homeowners and small business owners with repairs, renovations, and other household tasks. Meanwhile, the PDX Housing Solidarity Project is re-imagining community care through housing mutual-aid actions like paying off credit card debts, providing money for down payments, co-signing leases, and facilitating off-market home sales, which make it easier for Black families to access real estate at lower costs.
